TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was baptised in accordance with the ceremonial rite of the Jehovah ’s Witnesses and became an active member . On DATE he assumed the function of a preacher ( “ special full - time servant ” or “ regular pioneer ” – Sondervollzeitdiener , allgemeiner PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( LOC - kommando ) found the applicant fit to perform military service . It subsequently called him up ( ORG ) to begin his military service on DATE . That order was later revoked .
CARDINAL . The applicant , on DATE , filed a request with the Federal Minister for ORG ( ORG ) for recognition as a conscientious objector ( ORG ) .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , on DATE , the Minister for ORG recognised the applicant as a conscientious objector . Accordingly , he was exempted from the duty to perform military service but liable to perform civilian service ( Zivildienst ) .

CARDINAL . From DATE until DATE the applicant lived in a community of preachers ( “ GPE family ” – Bethelfamilie ) , which , in the applicant ’s view , is similar to a religious order ( PERSON ) and is called LAW ( ORG Sonder - vollzeitdiener der PERSON ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered the applicant to commence his civilian service ( PERSON ) with ORG ( ORG ) on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant became a deacon ( “ ministerial servant ” – Diakon , GPE ) within ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with ORG ) against the ORG ’s order of DATE , also requesting the suspension of its effect . The applicant submitted that he had been living in a community of preachers since DATE and devoted all his time to religious activities . On DATE he had become a deacon and aspired to assume the function of an elder within the Jehovah ’s Witnesses . Referring to NORP law ( section CARDINAL ) of ORG ) and the case - law and practice of ORG ( BVerwG , DATE , PERSON . CARDINAL C CARDINAL ) , he argued that persons in a similar situation ( preachers and deacons ) were exempt from compulsory military or civilian service . Further , the applicant complained that section CARDINAL ) of LAW exempted only members of recognised religious societies performing specific services relating to worship or religious instruction from the obligation to perform civilian service , whereas he held a comparable clerical position within the GPE ’s Witnesses . Furthermore , section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the newly introduced LAW on ORG ( Bundesgesetz über die PERSON religiösen GPE , hereafter referred to as the “ CARDINAL Act ” ) , which had entered into force on DATE , established that recognition under LAW was only possible after DATE existence as a registered religious community . Therefore this new provision precluded any recognition during the following DATE and made LAW inapplicable until DATE . The applicant requested ORG to revoke the restriction limiting the application of section CARDINAL ) of LAW to “ recognised religious societies ” , and in the alternative to revoke the DATE requirement laid down in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to deal with the applicant ’s complaint for lack of prospects of success . It further dismissed the applicant ’s request for his complaint to have suspensive effect .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , on DATE , the applicant agreed with ORG that he would begin his civilian service in an institution for disabled persons on DATE , and he consequently left the community of preachers .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant requested ORG to transmit his complaint of DATE to ORG ( Verwaltungsgerichtshof ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG granted the applicant ’s request .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant supplemented his complaint and requested ORG to institute proceedings to review the constitutionality ( PERSON ) of the wording “ recognised religious societies ” in section CARDINAL ) of LAW . In the alternative , he requested that the provision at issue be interpreted in conformity with the principle of equality . He thus argued that , in view of his position as a deacon in the GPE ’s Witnesses , he should be dispensed from the obligation to perform civilian service as his position involved supporting elders by guiding the communities , carrying out clerical work in cooperation with other fellow GPE ’s Witnesses , giving Bible readings , speeches and commentaries during worship and offering guidance for prayers ; accordingly , his functions were equivalent to those of members of registered religious societies who provided services relating to spiritual welfare or clerical teaching after graduating in theological studies , or to those of students of theology who were preparing to assume a clerical function .

CARDINAL . By a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed his complaint . It noted that LAW and in particular section ORG ) had not been applied and were not to be applied by ORG in the applicant ’s case . Rather , ORG had to apply section CARDINAL ) of LAW , requiring recognition of a religious society as a precondition for exemption from civilian service . The provision as such raised no concerns as regards constitutionality , since its objective was not to grant an exemption from the obligation to perform civilian service to every functionary of a religious community , whether or not it was recognised . It further held that the impugned provision , on account of its explicit wording , could not be interpreted in the manner suggested by the applicant . The decision was served on the applicant ’s counsel on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ended his civilian service and , on DATE , he rejoined ORG , where he stayed until DATE . Subsequently , he left the community of preachers , continued to work as a preacher and received further clerical training .
CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant began to do missionary work as a preacher in GPE and GPE .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINALa(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( PERSON ) provides as follows :
“ An exemption from the obligation to perform civilian service shall apply to the following members of recognised religious societies :
CARDINAL . NORP ordained priests ,
CARDINAL . NORP persons involved in spiritual welfare or in clerical teaching after graduating in theological studies ,
CARDINAL . NORP members of a religious order who have made a solemn vow , and
CARDINAL . NORP students of theology who are preparing to assume a clerical function . ”
CARDINAL . For a detailed description of the legal situation in GPE in this field see GPE v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL ) .
